October 2012                      Social media networks are valuable tools for the public outreach needs of transportation providers: they are free, instantaneous, reach large numbers of people simultaneously, and allow for sideline discussions. When transportation providers are trying to notify large numbers of passengers about delays, drivers about construction work, or bus riders about re-routes, they can “blast” messages through social media channels to reach their intended audience immediately (the audience accesses these networks far more frequently than the websites of their local transportation agencies). The goals of social media in transportation are to inform (alert riders of a situation), motivate (to opt for an alternate route), and engage (amplify the message to their friends and neighbors). Ideally, these actions would occur within minutes of an incident.   This report analyzes the use of social media tools by the New York region’s major transportation providers. It is focused on the effectiveness of their Twitter feeds, which were chosen for their immediacy and simplicity in messaging, and provided a common denominator for comparison between the various transportation providers considered, both public and private. Based on this analysis, recommendations are outlined for improving social media outreach. A subsequent report will propose policies and recommendations for enhanced information and engagement with users. Some more info on the chain reaction…                           When we run the chain reactions, we will want to run them a couple times, hopefully out in the common space of the 4th floor, then probably separate them into individual parts and run them again back  in the class room, and talk about them. We would love to see your process when we talk about your Machines. Before you make your final parts you are probably going to do some simple prototypes to show yourself that it will take the alotted time, or knock over the next part, so show us how you tested/prototyped that part.   So, a couple points to emphasize that we didnt in class:  Document your chain reaction. We will ask you to put up pictures or sketches showing how you tested your theories of your machines, or prototyped out your parts. Take pictures, make sketches, put em out when we talk about your Machine. I suppose if you all document the stuff on your individual blogs/sites, we could pull those up during discussion, rather than printing out a bunch of stuff, if you prefer.   Make your Machine re-settable. If it absolutely has to explode in an enormous fireball, then bring spare parts to do it again a couple times, but ideally this is a machine you can re-set, re-use.   Thanks,  Pete and Stephan                  This entry was posted in Uncategorized on February 8, 2015 by Stephan von Muehlen .                                             The Beginning Engineers’ Checklist and Akin’s Laws                           Hey folks,   These lists are incredible practical, insightful, and kind of funny. Please read them and come prepared to discuss them in class next week.  Be able to share at least one example of how you applied some of this advice to the mousetrap/chain reaction assignment!   http://makezine.com/2011/03/30/the-beginning-mechanical-engineers-checklist/   and   http://spacecraft.ssl.umd.edu/akins_laws.html                    This entry was posted in Uncategorized on February 6, 2015 by Stephan von Muehlen . That said, you can find the basic stuff here–course description, schedule, homework. Who knows, maybe as the class develops, we will get fancy and add more content.
